column1: Type 1 diabetes is a lifelong (chronic) disease in which there is a high level of sugar (glucose) in the blood.
Insulin is a hormone produced in the pancreas by special cells, called beta cells.
Insulin is needed to move blood sugar (glucose) into cells.
This buildup of glucose in the blood is called hyperglycemia.
With type 1 diabetes, an infection or another trigger causes the body to mistakenly attack the cells in the pancreas that make insulin.
